I think veterans should have preference over people who have not served in the Armed Forces. I think soldiers should get three day passes with out the pass being emergency when he is up for special duty.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The race problem will be the biggest problem confronting the nation in the post war era in respect to social justice; city + state rights + peaceful living conditions. Suggest as a start - mixed schools + teachers throughout the country; Bar no jobs to any person with the ability; Inforce laws of justice in hotels, night clubs, restaurants, + most of all on railroads in the south.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The  only thing that I have to say about the conditions in the United States is that I hope that the Government will do something about Jim Crowism because if I get married and raise a family I want my children to have the best and they cant have it the way they are Jim Crowing Negroes out of college where they can get special training.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: All I have to say is that Im glad there are arrangements being made to take care of the soldier after this war.  Because the soldier is not going to be as easy to get along with this time as he was in the last war and that is really the truth

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I do believe that conditions for the negro will become worse - because - the  of the negro is becoming to[o] strong - In order for the White man's supremacy to keep going he must keep the negro. The only thing for the negro to do is fight as he did in the South Pacific and Africa and France.  The negro must be prepared to fight and die so that his children  will be treat as human beings. The negro must stand to-gether and fight for their own freedom -  These conditions will exist in the South. The north will be a key for the negro.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The Army so far as its relation to me is rotten. I will not under any conditions serve again.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I hope that working and living conditions will be better after work hoping that it will give us a chance to put in practice the Yearning that the Army not giving us as part of our life work and I sure it will make better citizens out of all of us.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: If this segregation is not stamped [stopped] there will be continuous trouble. Many of us will never stay in the Army after the war for that reason alone.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I have never approved of the army method of discrimination against the Negro soldier and the policy of sending Northern soldiers down to face the Jim Crow tactics in the South. Also the policy of forever keeping the colored man down underneath a white man regardless of his rank or in most cases nationality where I have seen occasionally cases in which German and Italian prisoners have been accorded more respect and allowed more privileges than the colored soldier who is fighting for a country that doesn't appreciate it.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I would like to see the principles of Democracy which we are fighting for elsewhere, practiced here at home.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I believe that there has to be a very definite change in the social policy and in the government to have the democracy for which we are now fighting.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: After the war the Negro is goin g ing to find a caucasian race (especially in the south) united against him because of the fear of their displacement,  going to need all the legal protection possible.  This country as a democracy has ple[d] ged them that protection. It is the kind of deceitfulness that this country practices that provides fertile soil for revolutionary movement in any country.  It is time the U. S. forgot - prejudice - segregation - etc. and "got on the ball"

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I think things will be better for me after this because the attitude of the world have changed in regard to the negro

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I believe those men in the upper age brackets with around 3 years service should be the first to be discharged. Of course that depends upon whether they have responsible positions to return to and the amount of their responsibility at home.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The American Negro has been a special column for the country from infancy to the present time.  thru all of the dark times and up into the light he has had insurmountable trials and tribulations.  Why is he not given more consideration.In the future as in the past a small stem grows until it sometime blocks the form and progress of all others and so I see this particular subject.The people of the whole world must be content as a unit in order to be happy and happiness is the one and only means of our not having to maintain an Army of Occupation.  Those in the service are looking forward to the time when he can get back to a pre-Pearl Harbor states so why not all pull together so this may be accomplished.  Lets try and take care of two birds with one stone,  Anymosity for one another is not the way out.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: In Header: Artillery and put them in What you May Called a shit group. Answer below question 85.: The Army has taught me something that will be a lasting memory. The experience  from this could not be bought with money. I realize that I am an American, because I was born here, but for this being a war on, I must admit I have been treated worst, worst to make you resist so that they can exert 2 or three yrs (years), in guard house. I have seen Sect. VIII given to men for talking back to  and Southern Comm. (Commissioned) officers. If these conditions are existing now they will be even worst (worse) after. There are Many, qualified americans Negroes Who would appreciate using their Knowledge in helping this Victory to come sooner, but some how they have Seen fit to take Negroes out of Left Margin: The army and these Chicken Shit South-ern Officers Can Kiss My ass.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: For myself personally, I believe that I can always make out fairly well. For my people, The American Negro particularly in the South I believe that conditions could be improved a thousand-fold.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I. Moral:- The army is doing a very poor job of moral building in fact they are not taking it as a thing of primary importance. Since I have been in the army I feel more helpless than I have ever felt in my life. II. Classification:- The army has done a very negligent job of classification, consequently there are many unhappy soldiers. III. The Negro Soldier:- In many southern states the Negro soldier is treated more like a dog than a soldier. The United States must (underlined) have its support of the Negro and I think something should be done to give him more of an incentive. When that happens we will all be home by Christmas

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: (1) Classification of men capable of doing duty other and better than what they have been assigned to, There should be a better system of classification, because of definite cases that I know of where men with ability have been put in branches of the Service, where they could not exercise their ability. Whereas their training & education has been wasted - Therefore they were unable to give thier [their] best to their Country.  (2) The unjust treatment & unfair tactics that are employed against the Negro Soldiers. The average Barrack or sleeping place of the Soldier is overrun with Roaches - Ants - Bugs & Insects of every description. And there is ([underline] nothing [/underline] ) being done about it. The insufficient amount of food that is given the Soldier to eat - and the hardly eatable way that it is cooked. (Burnt - half done - no salt - and none on the Table at your disposal).

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I [underline]don't[/underline] in any way like the way the army, officers or any other part of it especially me being a negro down in this mother fucken South, with these pregistic Southern mother fuckers. I personally hope all these cocksuckers get killed. If you want to know who and why send for me. I'm in the 145th Port Co. Camp Plauche, La. just ask who wrote it, and I'll answer.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I think the army as a whole does quite a few unnecessary things.  For instance give an enlisted man an I.Q. test to see where he is best qualified.  I for one do not think my I.Q. of 113 was low enough to have been put into a labor battalion.  The gov't should give a man a chance to state what branch of the service he is best qualified &  then transfer him if he does not meet their required standards.  Another think definitely wrong is the chosen of new coms.  Each man selected for a new com should be given test & lessons in how to operate a particular class or teach certain subjects.  In my comp that is not done.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Instead of taking potential leaders while young and giving them an education expressly concerned with the handling of men, the army takes these men and gives them authority. Being untrained and unmindful of the psychology of their men, they give their orders in tyrannical fashion, thus producing a sullen reaction in the men to the non-commmission officers demands.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The Army might at least listen to some of the complaints made by EM [Enlisted Men] and not be so God-damned uppish about it. I don't mean to have every damned Tom, Dick and Harry air every God-damned complaint into the CO's ear but at least attempt to listen to the more  insistent ones. This God-damned air of indifference is what causes so many horses asses to chase discharges, go AWOL [absent without leave] and may be  in the end.  The Army should also pay more attention to a mans previous jobs and also his AGCT [Army General Classification Test] score before sending him to some ass hole of the universe to do something that he doesn't give a good God-damn about.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The Army will finance ty business after the war.  I will pay them back after the debt is paid.  The Army band I sever relationship forever I hope.There are two ways of doing things as we learned in the Army. The Right way; the Army way.   The Army way is HELL!!!Then too having to put up with a of ignorant Puks and their Southern ideas based on racial hatred makes Army a place for waste-matter (LATRINE) is a word for it.  I recall we had three C.O: in one week and each one never saw a pair of shoes till the age of 29 years.Its the damnest place a man may ever go- I was hog tied and dragged into the Army.  Why Ive seen better Bullshit in a pasture!!

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I do think we should develop better race relations now and after the war, so that the country as a whole will be a better place in which to live. If we should continue after the war with the feelings and existing circumstances after the war we are almost certain to have revolutions, riots, and what have you. These things can be avoided if given forethought and consideration.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: If all of the plans that are brought up before Congress or the House pertaining to the well being of veterans or any  personnel of the service can materialize we should have no worries as to economic or social problems. It is wise to profit by the mistakes made by the demobilization of the army on the last war. By doing that we could avert trouble that would be sure to arise if they (veterans) come back to the same United States that they left. All of this fighting would have been useless and so many thousands would have died or been maimed for no apparent reason.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I'm hoping that the people of the United States will realize the common brotherhood of man and treat all as such. There should be a greater participation of people in the elections and running of the government. Veterans returning to civilian life should not consider themselves as experts on how all state, local, and Federal government agencies should run. If the government can mobilize to fight an All-Out action in a military war, it should be able to combat unemployment and economic distresses with the same determination. If the greater majority of people can enjoy food, clothing, and shelter, on what we call the American Standard of Living, social living and conditions will become better. Equal and Identical opportunities should be given to all people regardless of Race, Creed or Color. That's what we are fighting for and it's worth it!!!

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85) [cont.] A continuation page
q85: The United States after it will have sacrificed thousands upon thousands of men to win a socalled war against tyranny, intake none in the interest of freedom, justice, and liberty, etc. It should see to it that its own people have some of those things. I have been puzzled by the hypocrisy of this Government. Which will not even protect its own soldiers against abuse by another civilian. They have been murdered, insulted and suffered some of vilent of treatment accorded to any human beings living or dead simply because of color. A Negro soldier doesn't feel so hot sweating it out on the Ledo Road when he knows when he returns what kind of treatment is going to be accorded him. Despite all of this we are giving all that we have in order to make the world fit to live [insertion] in [/insertion] . Fit for all people. No man should be denied the right to aspire as high as God will permit. Despite the war the aim in this country seems to be to keep the Negro people  and other minorities oppressed. I am afraid all of the blood that has been spilled is going to be in vain unless we wake up. I believe if as much time had been devoted by some people to winning [insertion] the war [/insertion]  as they have toward trying to keep certain other people in their places, the war would be much nearer the end.  However I believe that in long the American people will rid themselves of some of the hate and prejudices and we will certainly be in position to lead the world along the road toward peace and happiness.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I feel that the government should provide many more menus for the ex-service men to adjust him self to civil life after the war, than was done before.  The soldier should be given a chance to borrow money or any other means to hasten this adjustment. Many won't be able to  dry  out their plans, and should be helped in any way possible. Men with families will have much more reponibilitys [responsibilities] , and should be among the first to be let out of service. I also feel that we should keep a force so strong and well trained that no other nation will dare to attack us. We must start on these plans now and not wait until the war is over, because it is our way to forget as soon as the danger has passed.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: After this war, I will still be a Negro. This is as I would have it. However, it will be "Negro" with a capitalised "N". My every effort will be directed toward recognition of the Negro for what he has accomplished in his contribution to a society which still denies him his proper status and attempts to compromise the issue of equal opportunity by shouting "Social equality". No intelligent Negro wants social equality - he does not have it in his own race and the Social Register proves it does not exist in the white race. "Social Equality" is the cry of the ignorant who are fearful that the negro, if given equal opportunity, will surpass him. This viewpoint is justifiable in a sense when it is realised that so many negroes with almost unsurpassable obstacles placed before them, due to [insertion] the [/insertion] discrimination and prejudice of these same alarmists have become world leaders in their field. I believe in equal opportunities for all peoples. I am not in this army to defend a nation which will continue to foster the principles which places the most intelligent, cultured and accomplished Negro at the mercy of the most ignorant, uncultured and shiftless white man. To that I advocate education - of both races. Prejudice is the illegitimate offspring of ignorance - and it exists within each man. This defence mechanism of prejudice which I believe to be nothing more than a manifestation of an inferiority complex which, again, is common to certain clans of both mens, will be gradually removed as generation succeeds generation, and as each man learns more of  him & more men  , mutual respect among men will manifest itself. Then, and then only will the true spirit of Democracy be achieved.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: After the war thing's will have to change in the United States. The soldier who returns home will expect, and should have, a good job. Now while we are in the army the people on the outside are making good money. When we return we expect to make just as much if we do the same type of work. Before the next war the United States should have enough men available to have all the officers they would need. Some of the officers they have now 'stink.' I don't guess I need to say anything about the way Negro troops are treated while in the army. The U.S, as far as Negro soldiers are concerned, does nothing to help, keep morale up, or make a Negro proud of his uniform. Most of the soldiers returning home will find things changed. What most of them will want to know is just where can I get a job.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The army could have better facilities for soldiers, especially Negro soldiers. All soldiers are in one Army; They should be treated as on, and not separate groups If they cant live in the Army together, how can the two live in the U.S.A.?  At one time there were pamphlets of this same nature to be filled to better the condition of the soldier by knowing his grievances. There has been no change in the betterment of the soldiers.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The army - The army is what one makes it. I believe I make it signify a waste of time, as for as my future is concerned. On the other hand others may take it as they would any job and do themselves and the army a lot of good.  Conditions Post-war - After this war just like after World War I we shall drop back to where we were. Where we were was: ignorant race haters; depressions period due to land lease and other necessary legislation; disillusion for many ambitious persons; and last but never least tears that man never bring back the dead, or restore lost limbs, lost motions, or lost hearing or sight. You shall have to pardon me, but I am just a negro blowing off who thinks he knows what the score is.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I think conditions in the U.S. should be somewhat better after the war, for this war shall have caused people of both races to see that all men can live together and that all men are equal. They will realize that if  is good enough to fight side by side with another, no matter what race or color they are, then they are good enough to live together & work to their mutual benefits.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I have been increasingly disgusted with the political trend of the country for the past four or five years; in fact so[insertion] [/insertion] much as I hardly thought it was worthwhile to vote for any Senators or Representatives from my state in the past election. I shall probably do so for the national election as well. My reasons are plain [underline] disgust [/underline] and feel that if I voted for either party it would be the selection of one bad one in pre-ference of another. The ideals that Wendell Wilkie and Vice-President Wallace advocated are the things I would like to see for [insertion] our [/insertion] future. To see such things smothered under by power politics makes me wonder if we are progressing or falling into the things we are supposed to be fighting against.  As for the Army I have become convinced that it is biased, discriminatory and prejudiced. There should be stronger  carried out by the War Department down to the lowest echelons of the Army, and not so much left up to subordinate commanders who are in large degree responsible for the biases, discrimination and prejudice.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Unless the relationships between all races is greatly improved, this war or any war fought for "Democracy" will have been in vain. Barriers will have to be broken down with equal educational, recreational, and economic advantages. Not only in isolated sections but nationally all peoples must learn, play, and work together to live in peace.  If such a thing is possible, some sort of "Know yourself" school should be put into operation with a universal motto of "Do unto others as you'd have them do unto you."

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I might emphasize the fact that the reason that prompted this little interview is by far one of the most important things to be considered in this post war world. Too much stress and time cannot be spent on plans for the soldier returning to civilian life. Let us correct by experience the mistakes we made during World War 1.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I think the war has done good by some people to an extent because it has given them time to consider most, and think of economical, social and personal conditions which he was confronted with before the war and compared them with what he would like for it to be after the war, and by that probably he will take advantage of his conclusion and endeavor to make it a better country and world for everyone to live in.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I really don't know how the conditions after the war are going to be, but I'm hoping and praying that conditions will be changed a whole lot for everyone. In fact I don't think anyone really knows just how things will be after the war, people can only guess about that. I think, however, that everyone sill profit to a certain extent by this war. The people who were sleep will wake up and by them waking up to certain things this world will be a much greater place in which to live. Maybe individuals will realize that all men are created equal and as a result destroy this thing call discrimination. Race, color, or creed doesn't have a thing in the world to do with having a great democratic country in which to live.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I haven't very much to say on this subject, only this. I guess you can probably tell what outfit I'm in from the answers to various questions. I guess you probably know, that it is an all-Negro outfit and that its doing a hell of a job (for the first one of its kind,) along with several other all-Negro Units. The Negro has proven that he is comparable and sometimes superior to other races in warfare, and I'm sure that he can give the same results after the war, if he is place on an even basis, socialy, equally with other Races right here in the United States. It's the thing all of us are fighting for right now and I say let's [have?] it here first before we try to enforce it on others. That's all I have to say.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The United States is learning a lesson as a result of overconfidence and intolerance of all things opposed to her whims and fancies. Blood is a bitter wine to drink when the four so called freedoms are not enjoyed by all. Democracy is not just for some or a chosen lot but for all. The negro is fighting for his share of those freedoms. Will he be denied them?

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I would like to know why a Negro is asked to fight for his country when he is not considered a part of it. I would liked to know why the A.R. issued from the Adjutant General on segregation on armys posts has not been complied with. (For Knox, Ky.) I belong to the 477th Bomber Group and I would like to know why all the Squadron have white C.O.s when there are colored men qualified for the job.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: After this war the people should realize that all races are the same and there should be no discrimination or segregation against any race, creed or color. The minority should at least be given economic equality and social equality is somewhat minor. All ex-servicemen, and women should be given preference for governmental jobs, and State jobs.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I feel that all men regardless of race- color or creed- especially in the continental in the continental U.S. should have equality in all voice of government- and social activities

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I believe that the state of living in the USA would be heightened if negros were treated as true Americans. Being a negro in uniform who loves this country I become very bitter when I am discriminated against. Without a doubt the Federal Gov't could do much more that's have done in the past. The negro soldier is in a most embarrassing position in the Army. He is told he is fighting for freedom from fear, want, religion and alas against Nazism. Yet every day he is denied what is rightly his in the Constitution of the USA. I feel that if I should die in action it would not benefit the negros at all under the present conditions.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I have no share in this War as a Negro.  The sooner I am really out of the Army, the better I can produce, as a single consumer unit to the betterment of my personal states and that of my People and Country (?).  As a Negro I realize the truth of the maxim that Negroes are last to get hired and first to get fired.  That is my conception of the post-war world (pre war, too).

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: God dam the following and may they be condemned to Hell forever 1 The army which I served 2 The God dam south 3 The God dam chicken shit officers which I served under 4 The God dam army officials 5 The God dam army chow of which we never get those steaks and ect. 6 Oh! What's the use. Just [insertion] kiss [/insertion] my ass and go to hell anything connected with the army

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I am not quite sure how the United States will be after the war (whether they will have a depression or not). So therefore I am not quite sure what I will be able to do financially.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Yes, would it be the same after the war is one or would it be worse. The government say[s] that all the men in the arm[ed] forces, when they get back there will be jobs waiting for them. I don't know if it [is] true or not. And they be jobs so they can start up their own business. Well, I hope it [will] be that way for all the men in the arm[ed] forces and when they come back they'll be proud of this country and better world for all the people to live in, and all people are created equal no matter the color or  creed  That[s] all I ['ve] got to say, God bless America.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: My ideal of something that I can't understand is they will keep a man on this side and won't send him across sea's but at the same time they will send him so far away from his home that he can not see his people. there are a lot of camps all over America that are clost to every soldier home and the  safe?  if he could see his people a little more often he would be a better soldier. A lot I think that they keep a soldier on this side to long after and every time he get into a good outfit they break it up and ship  some  of them ever where, some teaching training and doing every thing. I would  rather?  be sent over sea than to continue being shipped out to take over recruits and just as soon as they get good soldiers have to start over again this has happen to me so much now and being as discourage I have become very unhealthy and the strain of all this train with out action has made me a very tired man. no much good for anything.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: 1st before the war we as a Race of Colored People was deprived of our right and justice. second, I would like to know very sincerely will we as a race of Colored People obtain our Liberty rights and priviledges as Citizens of the United States of America. demoilized Anti. lynchig. Rights to note especially in the south where they hafe for got what the Civil War ment to the Colored race. Colored and white go to school. together ride the same train and Buses not take the back seat. Most of all be call Niger. What I hate so bad. Rights to start a business in any City or state. We desire with ease with the help of the war Zt.D. To have more Colored officers in the army more colored politacins judges senators Administrators ect.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Men who have seen combat been in the army longest, wife and kids, be the first to be discharged older men should b discharged automatcly.paragraph]Men goldbricking should help each other or be put out the army.some of these company Commanders are suppose to get passed at soon at 1200  the passes are stamped for noon but yet we don't get them until 6:00 I don't think that write. We are in P.O.M. training most of the old men are well up on their training but yet they wont give up three day passes.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: It is my opinion that most soldiers do not worry of the outcome of this war - But there are small things which can if given a little consideration make us feel much happier. Such as unity between the first Sergeant and the men whom he should know more about than the commanding officer. A man who is not afraid to speak his opinion regardless of being afraid of loosing his rank.  In doing this most every one will be happier and they will be much better soldiers in any place in which a problem of this kind exists. for  things would be one thing that will help all safely have to our families again and that in unity cooperating to the very best of our knowledge.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I don't think men should stay in the army six months after duration for three reasons: most soldiers wish to get back home to there wives and children also thing a soldier has enough hardship to stay in which after the job is done. I firmly believe that through volunteered method that a large enough army can be made.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Nothing but good luck to the boys what left behind in the army  server  and would the negros have a better chance after the war when they come home I hope they won't bet [beat them up and kill them like they did before. Good luck and goodbye to all from and unknown soilde [soldier]

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: [insertion] [/insertion] I would like to no[misspelled] if [insertion] [/insertion] above word "negro" my child will have the same xx as any other child would. would the[inserted between words] negro ni[crossed out] have a better break after the Army. And would it be bad for him I hope it will be better for him. We have[inserted above] allway got a bad break out of life, why arnt[misspelled] the negroes like the other men. we are all human men and men anywhere. I hope my child will  better then[wrong word] I did.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I would like to know if the Negro would get their freedom of  democy  after this war or where they still be under modern slavely. And most of all would the Negro children get the right amount of education  w/ same ?  , as far as keeping them in the dark. An if not the  amount. I draugher not let them have have peace at all. Was the Negro of this so call Unite State of America, are comming home, but not under this modern slavery but to fight for our wright an to be given our freedom or none at all. An most of all not to be huten an kill on account of some white women statemen. But to be given a equal write to state his side of the thing as well as hers. But as far as modern slavery. I want to know whether the Negro will be free or still under the white man jurisdiction.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I don't think the married men and the men over 25 years of age make a good a Soldier as the youth between the ages of 18-25 because he is in poor physical condition and it is harder to change his civilian ways of doing things to the army way and he worry about family, home, and the future more, that combined with the anxiety of entering actual combat make him less efficient than the younger soldier. document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I firmly believe, much to my regret, that the American people do not really believe in what they are supposed to be fighting for. With a hypocritical smugness born of years of continual rationalization instead of self-criticism, most Americans loudly proclaim the four freedoms with one hand while with the other they continue to oppress minority groups in their own country. Racial groups who have fought, bled and died in an effort to keep this country "free" have been treated in much the same manner as the people of those countries we are fighting to liberate. Only a people who have lived and suffered under oppression can know the real meaning of the word "equality." America has long since forgotten 1776. Americans on the whole have not suffered enough in this war to gain any moral benefit from it. Their suffering has been an individual not a mass basis. Then in war the American people have not been able to overlook their petty dislikes, discriminations and hatreds. How can these, who found no time to rise above their personal dislikes and hatreds in war ever hope to prosper in peace?

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)

So far as my plans are concerned a few minutes won't start to tell a complete story. They are so many. I was in school before intering into active service and when I finish school then I can tell just how my plans will be. I may have to do a little replanning.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: There really is no color bar when a bullet hits. I have bus driver carry pistols push you in back seats all on a military post. We are supposed to be fighting for our country. Black, red, white or blue we are still Americans. There should be no color bar in the army. My fellow soldiers are the best bunch yet. All we ask is a  deal for the future. I promise you if I ever hear the word darky, I'll be a  murderer  . The army has taken the sweetest time of my life. My nerves are just about shot. True I have the first time to go in sick call. Why. No doctor can help me. All I want is freedom, an honorable discharge. Will you help me get it.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I am certainly not in accord with the U.S.A. Army having segregation policys. I think we are fighting a war to  race and class discrimination. I think the army should be the first unit to abolish such policys. I certainly am not in accord with the treatment the Negro service man is receiving in the South. I only pray to god that I am not sent to an area where such harsh policys are practiced, ecause certainly I think it silly to fight for a cause abroad and let the same thing exist right here at home, believe me. I know what I am talking about because I was born and raised in the south and that's why I have spent the past five years in the north, because I certainly do not approve of these tactics in a so called Democratic State? I often wonder why we fight Facisism, Nazisism abroad and let the same exist right here in our own country, right in Washington State capital. Certainly I really don't believe the Negros are going to stand such punishment after the war. Certainly after I fight in the jungles and deserts I am going to want the same freedom and liberty as any other citizen to vote, for jobs and certainly to be able to live as others.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Well I do think that the Government of the United States should fulfill the Constition of the U.S. and let all laws of the United States apply to all men of the U.S. and that is a Citizen of the U.S. regardless to color or race. And there is no reason that one man should be supreme over another at the same  when they were born equal every one does have a dark colored face. There is no Men that are satisfied in living under a government and is not allowed to vote whether this man should or should not carry out the plans of the government. Some thing should be done about it because I think we all suffer the same consequence as the Allied forces and even work in Civilian life.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85) [cont.] A continuation page
q85: THINGS WILL BE WORSE FOR ME IF THE WAR IS [crossed out word] OVER SOON BECAUSE THE WHITE PEOPLE WILL THINK THEY ARE THE MASTERS OF THE WORLD, ESPECIALLY [insertion] OVER [/insertion] THE DARK RACES. document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Yes its about the discrimination which I think is awful and something should be done about it on the double. Because I figure one man is just as good as the other no matter what race creed or color period.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I had seen and been in places where negroes where not allowed. In getting jobs we always get the hardest ones and less pay but the whites one recieves the easy job and more pay. Every races white, yellow and red are place over us and given better breakes. What is the matter with us, are they afraid we are better than them and scarred to give us a break. Many of them have broken through that wall and fighting to bring more through. But  are called and patted on the back to fight for this so called freedom. We have been told that after this war there will be a lot of changes made. I hope and pray it will because I don't think  younger boys will stand for anything like that that happen in the last war. You have seen or heard of race roits already breaking out in different cities as you see us colored people are tired of being pushed around and waking up to received some of that so called freedom that belongs to us.

q85: I think the negro will be thrown out of the plants and other industries first of all. document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: To me, the one big blot on the Army record is its policy of discrimination. I have seen more bitterness and disgust written on men's faces serving in the campaign than ever before. We often ask ourselves what are we fighting for Democracy or civilized slavery? Among its courses the War Department should number a course in democracy, a true democracy as those unfortunates who have not been exposed to it may gather some of the true meaning. I have seen many potential qualified leaders rot, because their skin was black. Does this increase the efficiency of the Army? Why doesn't the Army give a man his just deserts, regardless of his race or color and quit ignoring his qualifications. I am referring directly to the omission and expulsion of negroes from the MAC, Coast Artillery, Field Artillery, O.C.S. school of the Adjutant General and the Armored Command.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: As for conditions in the United States after the war, all I ask is that I as well as others of my race which is Negro be given a fairer chance. Within myself, I feel that without prejudice of any nature existing our country will be a greater one by far.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I am of the opinion that the Army personnel and classification sections are woefully inadequate. Men with degrees from leading colleges of the U.S. and high A.G.C.T. scores are cast to doing menial tasks which could be performed by any normal man with a grammar school education. No effort is usually made to correct these conditions unless the oppressed man is able to secure influence or pressure from outside sources. This applies specifically to members of the Negro race. Quite often Negro troops are commanded by race-prejudiced officers who are not usually relieved of their commands until outside pressure or influence is brought to hear

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: (1) Altho the Gd Bill of Rights has been made a part of our legislature there are clauses in it that will not cover the returning soldier that is faced with unemployment. Many who will be unemployed will have wanted to return as students (full or part time), but because of responsibilities will not be able to take in the education or its dependency benefits because the $75 allotted as a full time student with dependents is not sufficient, nor is the unemployment payments. (2) As yet no definite plan of returning men from the Army to civilian life has been evolved. The system of getting men into the Army was well-developed, & almost flawless; let us  the same system used for getting men back into civilian life. It is a lifetime problem and as important to the nation's welfare as was the placing of the right man in the right spot, and having a sufficient number of trained men.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The Subject of Equality both Political and economic for all U.S. citizens regardless of race, creed or color is constantly on my mind and frankly I think very little is being done to protect minorities now or provide for their future. The wanton discriminatory acts of cruelty and injustice heaped on the families of American Soldiers (Negro) and even sometimes on soldiers themselves makes the spirit of the Negro very low indeed. It is impossible to have good spirit and be willing to give all for a cause that you and your family will not have the priviledge of enjoying. The obvious indifference, hypocrisy, injustice and race baiting by our "Honorable" public officials from the south simply infuriates me. The placing of obviously inferior men in positions of authority over more competent men because of color or race is rampant in the Armed forces (another cause of frustrated anger and low spirits). We are fighting (we are told) to give liberty and freedom to all people. This is the exact opposite of the truth in the case of the American Negro. Many criminals are simply proud men who refuse to bow to "Jim Crow." I hate Hitler, and all he stands for but there are those among us who advocate the same principles of a so called "Master Race" right here in the United States, "the champion of suppressed people." I think strong, positive measures should be taken to protect all minorities and assure them of what the Constitution is supposed to give them. There should be at least a glimmer of light to keep hopes and ideals alive. Political and Economic equality are the things most desired by the minorities - I can speak for America's largest, the Negro.

q85: yes - I have had the opportunity of going quite a few places since my army  service  , of meeting quite a few folk and observing the relations existing between men of all sorts, kinds and Colores. I'll say here that the U.S. Army had a golden opportunity to show how Democracy could or should be worked but failed. There have been times in which I felt deeply resentful of the uniform I wore of the country which was backing that uniform - because of the color of the skin that wore that uniform was subjected to undergo. The rotten and lousy practice and policy of the War Dept of following out a pattern of Discrimation and Segregation has to my personal opinion made a working Democracy almost impossible during the Post War period. This too, has created  withus  the thinking and fair minded Citizenry, the possibility of always keeping the pattern, which is very tragic indeed.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: 1. The war has brought out a better racial understanding between nations and races. 2. I think that with the help of the government after the soldier will be able to find work.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The war at present is nearing its end according to reports. I think a soldier in the army 3 years at present and has had foreign service should be released or discharged if he was a draftee. Nearly all of us feel we had a *dangerous*  part and are proud of it. Those that are lucky enough to return back from overseas with 18 months of foreign service. And get our jobs back to get adopted to civilian life. The units I am in or outfit they really dont have anything for us to do. I spent 3 years *anti aircraft  Illegible  ) until now transferred to Infantry. I just cant get adjusted. I think its best I was home taking care of my family and preparing for the future.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The soldiers don't get the rations from there CO. like they should at least the P.V.F. don't. The CO. seam to try to keep the P.V.T down. Training the privet is O.K. But not  and trying to  them. That why so many of the P.V.T be in trouble. That goes for the  Dept to.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Conditions in teh USA after the war should improve considerably. People should not be denied their rights because they may belong to a minority group, Race or religious organization which is not as powerful as another may be qualification should be. Qulaifications should be the Basis for denials and all men should upon request be given the chances to improve their capacities to do various jobs efficiently. There has always been many Loop holes that allow officials methods to easily deny various persons the rights that were intended in passing certain Bills. It is your duty to see that these Loop holes are plugged.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I am in favor or selective service for young men after the war. It will mean much to them and their community. A lot of men in this war have been helped by securing healthy bodies as a result of good training. It will also be very educational for our young men. They will get a chance to go places and see things as well as  mingle  with youth from all over the country. I for one am greatly in favor such a requirement.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I beleive that after the war a soldiers individual condition will depend upon his initiative. with so many opportunities in this country theres no reason why he should depend upon any "soldier benifits" to carry on. Personally I simply look forward to a speedy victory and believe that in short time after, I will fit into civilian life and occostum myself to it as in the past.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The reason I requested for a transfer for the infantry, I was was in Field Artillery and was transferred to the Air Course. I did not like that part of the Army for the simple reason I Came in the Army to be a pilot but did not get it and the job I had there was in the med.  Det  but I wanted to serve overs sea and I know that I would never get it as long as I was in the medical corps. I like action and i want to be a soldier, so now I think I will get what I want, if so, I will be very happy, even if it is rough, I am sure I can take as much punishment and be a good fighter as any one else.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I am one that feel that enlisted men with more than three years of honorable service that desire a discharge should be granted  same  upon the defeat of Germany.  I believe that an Army of two million men would be sufficient in safe guarding America's future.  I do believe that we are now headed for another depression.  I believe that we soldiers of today will be the forgotten men of tomorrow.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Something should be done to bring the soldier upon the same level as his fellow human beings in some camps I have been in it is almost impossible for a soldier to meet the better class of girls.  the opinion of lots of girls I have talked with some girls seem to think being seen in public with a soldier is a mark against their name.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Well, I feel that after the war that things should be much better for the people of United States whether it will or not. Anyway it should bring about a more closer union among the people, because it has  Kinder of throun  them all together in a likewise  situations  . Such as Capitalists and non-Capitalists also racial feeling.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The army may be alright for some people but for me I think I have been  something that were not my duty for one thing the thing we have to go throu we don't have much  an what little we do have we have to be the tail end of everything but after the war I believe things will be better for there won't be as many to you with everything you do and all time having you do things when you are not the one that the cause of it. I think the brunt of the army rools are very poor and I would love to be out more than any thing else I no.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I think some provisions should be made to look out for the ex-service men when the war is over. Especially in giving him a good job. Because the most of the men have sacrificed a lot. There isn't any future in the army. You can only go so far. Every man is trying to gain something and there's only a little that the army has to offer.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: We were in CAAA [Crane Army Ammunition Activity, Crane, Indiana] Regt [Regiment] we served 19 months overseas as and [an] AA [Antiaircraft] outfit[.] when we return we were broken up and serve as Gen Bn [General Battalion] , with all train along units  other  men[.] a few weeks ago we were ship to a camp and then transfer to an Inf [Infantry] outfit where all of us are lost.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Well i do hope that the Nigro Race will be able to [insertion] go [/insertion] where ever they want Two & two work and get with White & be able to hold the job that he  for no matter if he is a Nigro. Because we left our home like the White did.' The one that be so Dear to us But there be so many things I could t down how but Will it do any good But i do Sincerely hope that when this is over we will Get a better Deal For the Nigro Race.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I hope the war will soon end and i havent been in action yet and if i have to go i think i am qualified enough to go and help get it over. and after it is over i hope we can go back to our family and live in peace.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I should want to hope that after the war, since our Negro troops (and they are Americans too) have fought with the rest for the same thing, will get the advantages that are due them for the job that they have done. And also that the South wake up to the fact that the Negro is no longer the under dog, that he is anyone's equal in intelligence, aptitude, straightforwardness etc, more so than a lot of these. They don't  equality as far as racial  sociality  is concerned but equality in advantages. Then everyone can see what they can and will do.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85) [cont.] A continuation page
q85: I have learn a good deal about the army   have been in service. And I think that it will be better for us after the war.  to stay within the area. If one should venture into one of the  P.X.'s  of an other area he is given to understand that this is a white Post Exchange and his patronage is not welcome nor received. Little do they seem to realize that this is also a white man's war the Negro troops are giving up their families, jobs, homes, working fighting and dying for.  The government has written laws but have done very little to see that these conditions were rectified. In the southern camps there are very few men in a position to enforce these laws who are in sympathy with us.  You will note that I  dote  upon this subject extensively. The reason is that it has been foremost in the mind of mine and others that I have conversed with - This condition has been brought closer to many of us since we were forced to participate in this war. Many of us have suffered these insults after having risked our lives in foreign countries and consequently they have been harder to bear.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I'll wait and see

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: My main hope is that after the war Race relations will be better and Negroes will be given a fair chance to obtain jobs for which they are qualified. I also have a desire to see more federal intervention in instances where Negroes are mistreated solely because of color. Plainly speaking I desire to have Antilynch legislation become a part of our every day life.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I think living condition will be much better also will be better schooling.  I think in this war understanding between [insertion] race [/insertion] will be much better because of understanding each other faster fighting and soldiering together.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The living conditions will be better in the housing situation. Road building construction or new houses and farming situation will be better. There should be plenty of jobs in that field. I think this war should have brought a better racial understanding in the Armed forces, but the evil in people. I don't know whether it has or not. I don't think it is necessary to have a large Army after the war because we will have support our enemies, so bad that, will free up to fight us again.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I don't know exactly, but my idea is that it seems to me if an enlisted man in the army had a course which he was very much interested in there should be some way for him to go to school and be prepared for duty after the war, therefore it would not be as much time wasted by waiting until after the war to go to school as it would be to go now. As you know everybody have their own ideas about a thing, but a man would be much more interisted if he was studying for what he longed to be.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I haven't got anything to say about it I just don't know if this will be better or knot, but I hope so.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: To my opinion thinks we should have a standard army after the war. But that doesn't include the older men. I think the government should give the soldier a job and some financial start after the war. There are hundreds of soldiers in the armed service who are not physical fit for duty. Why keep them.  homes will have to be  after the war. That means starting all over again. Give us jobs an a fair pay that is all we ask.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I am hoping and trusting that times will be lots better after this war end. I do believe that times will be lot better for me in the future. and I hope the each and every service man in the army force won't have any trouble getting him a good job when they return back home because I know each and every one of us will try to get a good job. and the one that we are best fit for.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I am hoping each individule will be helped as much as possible to obtain a position which will enable him to be a citizen everyone will enjoy knowing.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Well speaking for myself the Army is alright in some branches of service and others are not worth a dam (excuse the expression) well for instance me I have been in the Army almost three years I volunteer and I am only a corporal and some of the fellows I know made 1st Sgt. in 6 months time it seems as if your C.O. picks the men he want to promote and too record is clean I never been absent or a.w.o.l. my record all the way thru is excellent I have even and soldier for 3 medals, two good conduct ribbons and 1 driver medal. I was always kept on  all the time. Well in some camps they don't look out for the welfare of the men in there  own   .  Well I must say this that if this war ever will end and I hope it will I'll never volunteer again unless I'm forced of course I do want to take in the Army a year or two after the war to go to some specialist school. Of course I would like to be stationed in my home state so that I may visit home once and a while I want to be a military police or maybe become a Physical Instructor.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Yes -- it is felt by me and those with whom I associate that equality throughout the Army has not been granted. That if each soldier no matter what creed color or race could feel reasonably sure that fair employment throughout the United States could be granted each of its citizens; a deeper interest on the part of all soldiers could be assured. That if the people chosen to represent the great masses of citizens [insertion] in the Senate and Congress [/insertion] could but realize the race hatred is costing the United States countless millions of dollars through the ages and the next and immediate mission of the Army should be  to correct this terrible mistake in this great democracy of ours.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The army has gone to extraordinary pains to work against "democracy" in spirit + in letter and to equal lengths to prevent the nature and true danger of fascists and nazism from becoming apparent to the solider. In Lieu of this potentially terrific spirit-instiller, it has had to build up morale by falling back on race prejudice(war against Japan), + a weak "strong man" thereby (to explain Hitler). Whether the army's protestations that it only reflects civilian opinion are true does not matter. The fact is that conditions in the US will be influenced by the Army mentality's mis-handling of the ideological aspects of war. What is now thereby + fake morale will after the war be translated into brutal+  fascist fact. The Color Problem,How To Combat Depression+ Arrive at Security, How to Discern+ crush home racism on sight- none of our soldiers on return will be any more capable of dealing with these problems than they were when they left/ if they're [unclear as good soldiers should. Only to what their officers tell them this fact most soldiers apprehend somehow if only vague and they are mostly uncertain + afraid of post war, in spit of their brave letter to the papers + Barracks

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Yes; I hope the government will provide means for the ex-service men after the war no matter if they are disable. As for myself I don't want to depend on charity to support my family.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The United States must make plans, then take positive forceful action on them, to eliminate the many injustices to various minorities based upon race, creed, or nationality. Equality of EVERY and ANY kind is the only acceptable basis for a civilized and fair relationship of one human being for another. For this I GLADLY serve as a member of the Armed Forces. For any less - discrimination, insults of southern areas, particularly while in what is understand to be the uniform of the United States Army - I again feel like "a prisoner within the US Army sentenced to punishment for the fallacy of "white" or any other kind of "superiority". The relative disparity of recreational opportunity for colored and white troops on and off post in good example of the need for application of the aforementioned principles. I am acquainted with these differences because my Army work is directly concerned with such.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The Army is overcrowded with Negro soldiers with nothing to do. Why do they retain them. We have thousands of qualified men doing nothing but shifting from camp to camp place to place. Their morale is on rock bottom their opinion of the army has changed. They hate it. Sooner the other idle hands will think the same and a conflict will arize sooner or later. I hope I never live to see it personally. I always make it a point to try and pacify the deep thinking soldier. Hes the one to watch. If you can keep him calm you have accomplished something. That of late is a problem. He's becoming more unruly each and every day. Its your problem not mine to figure out what to do for the Negro soldier.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I joined the Enlisted Reserve Corps and took 6 months training in radio and was under the impression that when I was called to active duty I would be assigned to a signal corps outfit, but instead after completing basic training I was put in an Aviation Engineer unit as a basic (521) unloading and reloading box cars. I've practically forgotten everything I learned about radios now after being in the Army over a year and not having the opportunity to attend any radio school or be assigned to the Signal Corps. I've been promised that I would be sent to radio school at three different post, but it never materialized. I'm satisfied with what I'm doing now, but it is really disappointing to be faithfully promised something and you set your mind on it and yet it doesn't come through. If I could have gotten enough training n radio during my stay in the Army I would probably go into that field after the war.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I am hoping for governmental revisions that will make it possible for the government to make, and enforce whatever social or economic reforms that will be necessary to create a peaceful and united nation.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The problem of continuing full employment after the war is to me the most important post-war consideration. Servicemen expect, should have, and will have employment after the war. However if this is achieved at the expense of others, who through no fault of their own, did not serve in the Armed Forces - a cleavage between both groups will result and the possible outcome may be disastrous. Full employment will tend to give all a feeling of security, and make  the better competition for jobs, which brings about the intensification of moral and religious bias. A comprehensive plan now, will go a long way to allow the fear and suspicions about post-war employment opportunities.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Now that Negroes are fighting on all fronts and spilling their blood to keep not only this land but other countries as well free from tyraney [tyranny] and as I am a part of the army and some day may die defending our one cause Freedom  of  Demomcracy [Democracy] . My wish is that all the things we are doing abroad for other countries will some day be practiced here giving us as Negroes a chance to share in the Four Freedoms and not only us. Any citizen regardless of race color or creed. I love America because its the only country I know and if nessary [necessary] I [insertion] will [/insertion] die for her and tomorrow I wish to live in her as well and as happy as anyone else.  I am praying that my wish will come true in post war days if not before.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: well after this war I think thing will be much better for us who serve in this war  infaith  I hop so any way

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: What provisions will be made and inforced throughout the country that will suppress the segregation and its allied prejudices? You could answer this question to me but it will be a question that will be made an issue when the war is over.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I do think that there should be plans worked out to see that the Negro is given Fair Employment and Equal chance to advance from all angles. There should b e especially some kind of plans made for the Education facilities of the Gero schools in the South. 1. Pay for teachers 2. Classroom equipment 3. Qualifications of teachers 4. School Buildings 5. Compulsory Education. The five items mentioned above of valuable importance to the adjustment of the nero after the war.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I think it would be a good idea if the army discharges more colored men than white as soon as possible after the war. If the colored men get out of the army the men on a whole will loose contact with each other and there will be less chances for organized race riots.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Personally, I think what we have got to look forward to after the war is racial problems. And the time has just reached it's peak where we should really insure decomracy [democracy] a chance to function.  Would have to make some plans for the millions of servicemen that will be discharged from the army. We have got to have some particuliar [particular] job waiting for each man that leaves the service.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I believe that the vacillating attitude of the Administration in the treatment of the question of equal rights for Negroes & the strong resentment of the white people of the South & less so of the North has been a definite barrier to achieving a life of full opportunity for all the citizens of this country. I believe that there is enough in this country for all of us but there has been no concerted effort of the thinking people of the U.S. to make us feel that we are all striving toward a common goal. On the contrary, there has been too much work done to divide group vs group, race vs race, color vs color, religion vs religion & section vs section. The solution lies in more education, less propaganda & a greater effort of all of us to know the other fellow's problems & to help him solve them, thus helping ourselves.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: 20 or 25 years from I wonder if some other boy will have to go through all of this again? Will the big money men give the little fellows a break without putting a stranglehold on them. No is the answer of each and every one of us here. Will select the proper representatives in local state and federal government. With our ballot and the ballot only will the soldier especially the Negro soldier get what is rightfully his. With this, this United States will be a much better place to live in. This is the way I feel and can be quoted "don't sell out for money".

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: My request for Transfer to the Infantry was because I had been doing nothing but the easiest job in the army (clerk typist). My main object was to try to get something in Infantry that wouldn't permitt me to be soft. All I've done is gained nothing but weight, which seems just silly to say, but never the less in civilian life, I was active in many things that had to do with the rough and tumble of life not sitting all the time. I like my job but not what it offers [underline] physically[/underline].

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The one dissatisfaction I have with regard to the army is the fact I have not an opportunity to take a more tangible and definite part in the war such as actually going into a combat zone. My army job keeps me so busy that I have little time to plan for after the war. Further-more the future seems so in-definite. Often there are little or no opportunities in fields one might chose. Looking at a future, which seems quite indefinite, with a  point of view causes my plans to be definite  also. I feel that it is going to be a case of working for a living  whatever job is available rather than doing some work I would like to do.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Protect the Ex-service men we all will want jobs with enough decent pay to support our familys [families] . The race problem could be better  enhined  . Increase the discharge pay enough to tidy [tide] the man over for atleast [at least] six months. Ensure the cripple men a decent living

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I have stated that it is not run a small scale system. It's run on a large scale and therefore it neglects alot of minor details that knock out my moral and others. What I have to say about the United States is this, it's still not democratic. I a negro and I want better rights and I'm going to  demand them. Since I've been in the Army or as a matter of facts during the War I never seen [insertion] or heard of [/insertion] such a un democratic system in all my lief[life]

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I think that promotions should be given by competitive examination rather than by seniority or appointment. I  norcase  its educational facilities for class IV + V men. Do away with its from  policies and give  Negro  soldiers a fair and equal chance in all branches of the service

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: My main reason for being undecided about plans for the future is that before coming to the army I lived in Georgia and I am wondering just what my opportunities will [be] if I decided to return there to live, my family is there but what will the attitude of the people be toward my race that always has been quite an issue in Georgia[.] perhaps while the war is going on someone should get together and explain that there are lots more just like myself. I would hate to have to go someplace else to live and leave my family but after the war I intend to lead a very peaceful life.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Try and stop "Jim Crow." The Negro is a human being the same  Talmadge [perhaps a reference to Eugene Talmadge - "Dixiecrat" governor of Georgia 1933-37, 1941-43, and 1946 when he died in office]

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Why does officers feels or acts like a soldier is not much in his eye sight.
