document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: What will the situation of the colored race be after the war, if rights are not allowed then, when they are needed so badly by their country now?  Especially in the South!

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: What will the situation of the colored race be after the war, if rights are not allowed then, when they are needed so badly by their country now? Especially in the South!

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I resent all types of race prejudice. There is no need for it at all. The constitution ruled it out in same  but the rules are not enforced. The Federal Government could put an end to it without a doubt. My brother gave his life for a democracy and freedoms which do not exhist. Before this is over, I might be called upon to do likewise. I want to contribute wholly to this country, but cannot do it when ignorant people hold social predjudice over me. It is appalling to think that such a great nation as ours claims to be would let such a thing stand between corruption and perfection.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Something must be done to curtail the widespread unemployment that is certain to be. The jobs now offered all over are defense jobs and they won't be there when war is over. Then what??  A big chunk has been knifed out of the soldiers life. He is at loose ends. He has not benefited by the war financially and there will be nothing for him afterward.  I become frightened whenever my thoughts lean into the future. No family, no home, no money, what is to become of me. I will not be able to qualify for good jobs (professional) because of educational limitations.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I think that I have not received a square deal from the Army. I said this because, being a Negro soldier, I was at times subjected to treatment that no U.S. Army soldier should have received. While in Mississippi, we Negro soldiers were treated worse than enemy soldiers. We were puzzled at this strange treatment because we were making  sacrifices. Many of us developed a strong hate for white authority, the United States Army, and especially the Jim Crow South. I do say at that at times morale was so low in my outfit that some of us would have gladly sided the enemies in order to destroy white superiority. Jim-Crowism must be banished from the U.S. Army. Don't opposed the Race  Mangers  any longer - The eyes of the world are on the United States. Democracy begins at home!

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I only hope that discharge negro soldiers get a fair deal in post war jobs. After all they are entitled to a decent living just as much as anyone else. The motto of the employers should be "the best man fitted get the job."

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: There is only one subject that is on my mind and every other "colored" soldier. "The Racial Problem". The white people of the United States are not being as fair as they could & should be. Why should we go though all kinds of hell during this war to only come back to more hell. We are in here  like any one else with only a little hope and very much doubt to whether the Racist Problems will be solved. Just because we are boron or Black doesn't mean we are dogs does it? hell no. Someone better wake up and realize we are humans just as you or they are. All we are asking is a chance, can we have it. If we don't get the chance there is going to be plenty of hell someday. It is only 1 American give a human being a chance. Get wise and wake up to

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: 84 It depends upon the carrying out of the post war plans of the government.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I think the Army has taken a cowards viewpoint on the social question. On enlisting the Army I was rather proud and felt secure. After learning that the Army has done nothing to eliminate the beating and segregation shown her colored soldiers I've lost that sense of security. It's a poor Army that won't protect its own.  As tough  to  be  asked   to  give up your life to liberate others you need a little liberation yourself. The Army should in some way discourage this sort of thing. At least in Army camps where they have the authority to do so.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: If conditions became any worse for me and my race, there would be a revolution. My race is getting fed up with being push [pushed] around all the time and especially in the south. In the Army the negro is used mostly for labor and in nearly all cases where they are serving in some other way, it is only a small number in order for the army to say "you see we have some doing this or that. I am stationed in the south and German and Italian prisoners are treated better than I am.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I hope the Negro ex-service man will find the doors of Economic Opportunity open to him after the war.  The war brought many occupational opportunities for Negroes. I hope these same opportunities will be present after the war.  If they aren't, and Negroes are refused work, there will be much trouble. There will be riots and much strife.  Negroes are called to share the bloodshed of the Nation and they [underline] must [/underline] reap the benefits.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Racial problems are my greatest worry for I see each & every day evidence of the type of disturbances to expect when the war is over. Negroes are the greatest problem and I believe the problem should be looked at without prejudice or malice toward anyone. They can only expect human treatment after the war and surely they deserve. They have been kicked around long enough to deserve a fair deal by now. I am personally hoping that they are treated as humans; men & women: and given a fair deal. It is up to you to see to it that they are given the chance they deserve and if you don't "God bless your soul as it suffers in hell" for the wrong the white race has committed against the Negro race. Thank You

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I hope that after I return from over seas and back to this land democracy which I have  for, I shall find that those factors of new employment law shall be put in to full practice both in the plants and South. That this barrier of desegregation shall be destroy. We can be aided by better cooperation of our federal government. To see that all it's citizens are given an equal chance and an improvement of all functions of which the public is to participate. If I should return from the battle field and find the same conditions existing I shall beel that our war has been a waste and those who died have given their lives for nothing.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: As a man who is fighting for his country I do resent the manner in which I'm being treated down here in the south. I believe as Abraham Lincoln believes, all men are created equal. I do resent the retched Jim Crow system, all discrimination and other injustices that I, my fellow soldiers and all other colored people are subjected to. Though I'm patriotic (I volunteered) I sometimes ask myself why should I be so eager to fight for a country in which 1/2 it's people [insert](the south)[/insert] do not appreciate me and my kind. I could go on indefinitely, but the main point is that [underlined] I want some of the freedom for which I'm fighting.[/underline]

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I would like to have a fair chance of employment and the full benifit of my rights in the constitution of the United States of America. I have been denied a great deal privleges that were freely granted to people of other races, even Germans and German prisoners and Japs, that are supposed to be enemies of the United States and its Allies, and I am an American soldier and citizen and can't live in a place in my native land, that I would gladly give my life to defend. It's a shame, the whole thing, and I hope this condition will improve in the future.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I think that there are too many inefficient officers in the Army and that their standards of conduct & leadership should be stiffened.  I also believe there should be a closer check on those individuals who are responsible for the number of men drafted into the Army - in short there are numerous cases of fraudulent discharges & deferments.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The army as a whole has been fairly considerate but there is room for improvement especially on the discrimination issue. Minorities are not treated as equals and surely they have proved themselves worthy on every occasion.  They have shed their blood, and suffered the pains and aggonies of war without whimpering or asking what are "we" fighting for. I know they feel that they are not being justly treated but are still willing to sacrifice their lives so that the United States may be a greater country to live in.  I think it is the duty of Congress and every citizen in the U. S. to give the minority groups, the rights, the freedom, and the opportunities the white race have in this country and to enforce those laws protecting these peoples rights against the [underline] facist [/underline] in our land.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I hope that after the war that the constitution of the United States will be upheld to the fullest in as much as all men are created equal regardless of race, creed or color. That every one will be treated the same and a right to do what ever he can to better his country.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: The one portent issue as far as policy goes is the open discrimination against Negroes. Despite all that has been said and done the Army has stood steadfast in this regard. When the tide of battle warrents there is no hesitation in making a mixed army but when things are not pregnant when men might enjoy and appreciate the equality that they are fighting for they are denied it and often suffer rebukes at the hands of the civilians they are giving their lives for. Is there any other problem more fundamental or timely than these. Start out right after the war and a future war be it civil or otherwise might easily be avoided.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: This war, so they tell us, is being fought for democracy and equality for all. It's a shame that in this army which is supposed to be fighting for "democracy" there is so much race hatred and discrimination. A Negro soldier, while in the uniform of the U.S. Army and fighting for his country, must put up with all kinds of insults from civilians and other members of the armed forces. This doesn't give a man very much to fight for. Democracy whould start at home. The Negro soldier has more to fight for on the home front than "over there". Race discrimination should not have any place in this so called democratic country - but least of all in the army.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: There is one condition that will have to be worked on very strenuously after the war. If we as people of the United States expect or even hope to have world peace. We had better establish peace among ourselves as races. If we constantly fight among yourselves we will be divided, that way the country cannot stand. We must have Unity [underlined] . And it cannot be had by racial discrimination [underlined] . If that problem is solved, the thing we are fighting for will not have been in vain.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Well to explain myself as clearly as possible. I was born in the south (Ga.) Right now I am serving in the armed forces and am pretty displeased with the attitude of the white race to the negros. I am a negro so if I am to continue living in this country I would demand equal rights. I am now training to fight the eniemy but from incidents that have occurred to take direct effects upon me, I will gladly stand ready to oppose the systems of democracy. The city of which I was a native, has revealed some of the most inhumane occurrences to man and again I say that I will go as far as killing the opposers of equal rights among the different races in this country. Unless the leaders of Democracy can enforce its own laws, I am forced to say that it is a fraud.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: A total war should be waged on the agitators of "white supremacy" or some other measures to subdue them without delay.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: In my opinion mostly conscerns after matl of this war. I personally think that mustering out of soldiers at large quantities would be a menace to society. Seniority should play an important part in mustering out servicemen so they can all be taken care for working facilities. In the Army it is a large margin between the Enlistment Officers. After they are all suppose to be gentlemen. An Enlisted man was insubordinated to his senior, Officer also to his senior, Enlisted man punished by a long jail term, Officers just discharge from service as Officer. That's just a small incident.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I hope there [insertion] will [/insertion] not be another depression i the United States after this war.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I hope that we will not have to have a large standing army because of the expense and the dangers of professionalism. It is also my wish that more opportunities for service based on ability rather than other reasons will be allowed all persons; that in some way without injuring old men in the service when new men are given jobs they will be given the proper ranks and compensation. I also hope to see the class  which is determined by rank in the army disappear because it is not necessary for discipline as we have heretofore thought and often causes one to think in the terms of false personel values. There should be constant planning to meet the needs of future wars and preserve the peace so as to make for rapid expansion without as much waste of energy and materials. This should also be a country of equal opportunities, real justice and free for all after the war.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: Hope that the person will have the opportunity to   . I hope that would affairs will be conducted in a manner that another war will occur every people should be granted the right to a decent standard of living a right to equal opportunities, social, economic and political. The nation should have armed forces enough  to pre-war aggression  by any other nation. How is hoping that every citizen of the U.S.A. will have equal social , economic and political opportunities. The federal government should see to that regardless of state laws. No soldier or civilian can whole heartedly support his government if the government is reluctant about protecting his rights.

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)

q85: I feel that the govt. should help me to fulfil my plans that were stopped when I was drafted. No provisions are made for the older men going to school. We are the goats or will be after the war. Broken in spirit and no one to help us to further our education. Why?

document_type: A document that contains one question (Q.85)
q85: I don't have much to say but I would like a transfer to another branch of the Army preferably the paratroops.
